- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.

DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.

<target_code>
Here is the code of ignore_sigpipe:
```c
static void
ignore_sigpipe (void)
{
  struct sigaction oldsig;
  struct sigaction sig;

  sig.sa_handler = &catcher;
  sigemptyset (&sig.sa_mask);
#ifdef SA_INTERRUPT
  sig.sa_flags = SA_INTERRUPT;  /* SunOS */
#else
  sig.sa_flags = SA_RESTART;
#endif
  if (0 != sigaction (SIGPIPE, &sig, &oldsig))
    fprintf (stderr,
             "Failed to install SIGPIPE handler: %s\n", strerror (errno));
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler language extensions are used in the provided fragment. The code uses standard C constructs (static function, struct objects, pointer-to-function assignment via &catcher) and POSIX/OS APIs/macros (struct sigaction, sigemptyset, sigaction, SIGPIPE, SA_INTERRUPT/SA_RESTART). These are platform or library interfaces, not compiler language extensions such as GCC/Clang __attribute__, asm, typeof, statement expressions, nested functions, or other vendor-specific keywords. The conditional use of SA_INTERRUPT is a platform-specific macro, not a compiler language extension. Therefore there are no fragments that meet the Rule 1.2 criterion of using documented compiler language extensions.
